title: Eddie Jones sticks by George Ford for England's Rugby World Cup final
text:
Eddie Jones is poised to retain the creative alliance of George Ford and Owen Farrell in England’s backline for the World Cup final against South Africa on Saturday.

The head coach, Jones is boosted by the expected recovery of Farrell, Jonny May and Kyle Sinckler, who all suffered niggles in Saturday’s victory, will put his squad through an intensive training session on Wednesday before settling on the lineup to face the Springboks, but the indications on Tuesday night were that the midfield combination will not change.

Ford and Farrell operated in tandem, with Manu Tuilagi at outside centre, in Saturday’s epic 19-7 victory over New Zealand and it is understood that the same 10-12-13 unit will be selected together in Yokohama.

Eddie Jones is poised to retain the creative alliance of George Ford (pictured) and Owen Farrell

The likely decision to keep Ford at 10 comes after Jones hinted he would consider changing his winning team to combat this particular opposition.

After England beat the All Blacks he was asked about Ford and Farrell’s defensive efforts, saying: ‘They defended well but next week is another situation. We’ll look at how we need to play and what the opposition are going to bring to the party, then we’ll decide on selection.’

The next day, Jones and his senior assistant, John Mitchell, were in attendance to see South Africa edge past Wales courtesy of a try by their powerful inside centre, Damian de Allende.

This prompted speculation England would revert to the midfield combination of Farrell, Tuilagi and Henry Slade, as they had for the quarter-final win over Australia in Oita.

Head coach Jones is boosted by the expected recovery of Farrell (pictured) for Saturday

That was deemed a horses-for-courses selection to counter the threat of the imposing Wallaby centre, Samu Kerevi.

However, Kerevi weighs 15lb more than De Allende and England’s coaches will be mindful of the need to combat the Springboks’ tactical kicking game. Ford has been exceptional in that department in this tournament.

Meanwhile, it is understood that England have been fined a four-figure sum by World Rugby for their ‘V’ formation response to the haka five days ago.

authors: Chris Foy For The Daily Mail
